description: Uncertain. Short for cullion? Compare Irish cuallaí (“companion”)

entries.meaning: (archaic) A person who is easily tricked or imposed on; a dupe, a gullible person.
examples: One [attitude] was a fascination with street-walkers and courtesans as self-confident entrepreneurs, able to outwit their simple cullies.

entries.meaning: (historical, archaic) A male client of a prostitute; a john, a gonk.
examples: The assumption tends to be the opposite: Whores constantly seek sexual encounters to fulfill their burning desires and also sometimes manage to wheedle gold out of their cullies.

verbs.description: cully (third-person singular simple present cullies, present participle cullying, simple past and past participle cullied)

entries.meaning: To trick, to impose on, to dupe.
